s.text: Ernie Els alone among the final four had won an Open, but was a vanilla man, plain-looking and apparently without any emotions whatsoever.
The way to win is to shoot pars--on the fairway, on the green, two-putt for par, go to the next hole.
Many golfers win just one tournament in their entire career--some minor Kmart Classic sort of thing--and even the golfers who are good enough to win the majors tend to win only one or two.
Ernie Els alone among the final four had won an Open, but was a vanilla man, plain-looking and apparently without any emotions whatsoever.
Ernie Els alone among the final four had won an Open, but was a vanilla man, plain-looking and apparently without any emotions whatsoever.
It was 11 years since he had won a tournament.
And finally there was Colin Montgomerie, a multiple failure in major tournaments, surely the best player in the world never to have won one of these things.
Ernie Els alone among the final four had won an Open, but was a vanilla man, plain-looking and apparently without any emotions whatsoever.
Ernie Els alone among the final four had won an Open, but was a vanilla man, plain-looking and apparently without any emotions whatsoever.
Ernie Els alone among the final four had won an Open, but was a vanilla man, plain-looking and apparently without any emotions whatsoever.
Ernie Els alone among the final four had won an Open, but was a vanilla man, plain-looking and apparently without any emotions whatsoever.
The way to win is to shoot pars--on the fairway, on the green, two-putt for par, go to the next hole.
He waited and waited.
He waited for the group on the nearby 18 th green to finish.
He waited and waited.
Montgomerie wandered around the green, waiting for total silence.

No one has as much club speed, and when he strikes a ball, it whistles, rockets out into space on a line and then, astonishingly, rises, as though hitting another gear, some kind of warp drive, before parachuting to Earth uncannily close to where Woods wants it to go.
"Let's go over there and get Tiger's divot," I heard a fan say one day, referring to the tiny chunk of grass and dirt that Woods had scraped from the fairway on one of his shots.
Open, particularly Congressional Country Club's blue course, rewards conservative, risk-averse players.
And finally there was Colin Montgomerie, a multiple failure in major tournaments, surely the best player in the world never to have won one of these things.
Or maybe it is that the competition is so stiff that no single player can dominate like Arnold Palmer or Jack Nicklaus or Tom Watson did in their heydays.
Open, particularly Congressional Country Club's blue course, rewards conservative, risk-averse players.
The next hole, the 17 th , we all watched in gut-wrenching horror as Lehman hit his approach shot into the pond.
With a one-shot lead, Wiebe played the 17 th hole perfectly, hitting safely over a pond to the fat part of the green.
The man just did not want to hit the putt.
Just walk up and hit it!

No one has as much club speed, and when he strikes a ball, it whistles, rockets out into space on a line and then, astonishingly, rises, as though hitting another gear, some kind of warp drive, before parachuting to Earth uncannily close to where Woods wants it to go.
The man just did not want to hit the putt.
Just walk up and hit it!
Then Lehman hit into the rough by the 16 th green and lost a stroke.
The man just did not want to hit the putt.
Just walk up and hit it!
Everyone watching thought: Hit the putt!
He'd hit the wall.
The man just did not want to hit the putt.
Just walk up and hit it!

He was still tied for the lead, but that didn't matter, since the devastation of missing that putt ensured that, on the 18 th , facing an almost identically easy putt, three feet straight uphill, he didn't even catch any lip, missed it wide left, game over.

He was still tied for the lead, but that didn't matter, since the devastation of missing that putt ensured that, on the 18 th , facing an almost identically easy putt, three feet straight uphill, he didn't even catch any lip, missed it wide left, game over.

He was still tied for the lead, but that didn't matter, since the devastation of missing that putt ensured that, on the 18 th , facing an almost identically easy putt, three feet straight uphill, he didn't even catch any lip, missed it wide left, game over.
The world is a dark, cruel place.
They were men without color, literally wearing gray and beige and brown.
Increasingly I fear that golf has become auto racing.
